content.raw:
if you uncomment out the line in the above paste: 

>saved["metallicity"] = ad["gas", "metallicity"]

you'll get an error (full traceback below):.  similar errors come if trying to access the particle masses.  

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "junk.py", line 91, in <module>
    saved["metallicity"] = ad["gas", "metallicity"]

    self.get_data(f)
  File "/Users/desika/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py", line 623, in get_data
    self._generate_fields(fields_to_generate)
  File "/Users/desika/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py", line 640, in _generate_fields
    fd = self._generate_field(field)
  File "/Users/desika/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py", line 251, in _generate_field
    tr = self._generate_fluid_field(field)
  File "/Users/desika/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py", line 271, in _generate_fluid_field
    rv = finfo(gen_obj)
  File "/Users/desika/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/fields/derived_field.py", line 178, in __call__
    dd = self._function(self, data)
  File "/Users/desika/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/fields/fluid_fields.py", line 153, in _metallicity
    tr = data[ftype, "metal_density"] / data[ftype, "density"]

if you uncomment out the line in the above paste:

saved["metallicity"] = ad["gas", "metallicity"]

you'll get an error (full traceback below):. similar errors come if trying to access the particle masses.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs

content.raw:
Add a carriage return after the first triple backtick and before the last one.  Also it looks like those are single quotes not backticks.

You can click the <> button on the comment editing interface which will plop down a preformatted code block after asking you what language you want syntax highlighting for (python traceback in this case).
content.html:
Add a carriage return after the first triple backtick and before the last one. Also it looks like those are single quotes not backticks.

You can click the <> button on the comment editing interface which will plop down a preformatted code block after asking you what language you want syntax highlighting for (python traceback in this case).

pullrequest.title: Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs

content.raw:
another issue that i've uncovered in this PR: 

if you add a line to the example paste:

```
#!python

ad = pf.all_data()
print np.max(ad["density"])

new_ad = new_ds.all_data()
print np.max(new_ds["density"])
```

you'll get values roughly 1e21 different from one another.  (this is also apparent if you do a projection plot of the original pf and the new_ds).   i've been digging but can't figure out where the factor 1e21 comes from.
content.html:
another issue that i've uncovered in this PR:

if you add a line to the example paste:

ad = pf.all_data()
print np.max(ad["density"])

new_ad = new_ds.all_data()
print np.max(new_ds["density"])

you'll get values roughly 1e21 different from one another. (this is also apparent if you do a projection plot of the original pf and the new_ds). i've been digging but can't figure out where the factor 1e21 comes from.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs

content.raw:
though I should note - it's only the smoothed values of the particle data that is off by this huge factor.  the actual particle densities in the two data sets:


```
#!python

print np.max(ad["PartType0","density"])
print np.max(new_ad["PartType0","density"])
```
are comprable
content.html:
though I should note - it's only the smoothed values of the particle data that is off by this huge factor. the actual particle densities in the two data sets:

print np.max(ad["PartType0","density"])
print np.max(new_ad["PartType0","density"])

are comprable

content.raw: @desika I think this might give the right answers now.  I'm going to try to get your data and run with the pasted example, because it's on a currently down machine.
content.html: Desika Narayanan I think this might give the right answers now. I'm going to try to get your data and run with the pasted example, because it's on a currently down machine.

pullrequest.title: Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs
Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs

content.raw: @desika I've figured out the problem with the script, and resolved it.  It requires the updated PR, and a minor change to the script.  The particle masses are already in grams when they are put into the `new_ds` object, but we claim them as being in mass units from the other dataset.  Changing both `mass_unit` and `velocity_unit` to 1.0 in the `load_particles` call fixes it.  So, I think since this passes the tests, and it includes actual bug fixes, it should go in.  I'm running nose here (takes a bit) and have to take off, but if Fido agrees, anybody want to hit the button?
content.html: Desika Narayanan I've figured out the problem with the script, and resolved it. It requires the updated PR, and a minor change to the script. The particle masses are already in grams when they are put into the new_ds object, but we claim them as being in mass units from the other dataset. Changing both mass_unit and velocity_unit to 1.0 in the load_particles call fixes it. So, I think since this passes the tests, and it includes actual bug fixes, it should go in. I'm running nose here (takes a bit) and have to take off, but if Fido agrees, anybody want to hit the button?

pullrequest.title: Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs
Fixes for SPH smoothing in Stream outputs

description:
This adds a few helpers for SPH smoothing.  Most prominently, it supports making cutout datasets, with something like this:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4662/
